io.github.samwright.framework.model

Interface Workflow

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ChildOf<WorkflowContainer>, Controllable, Deletable, EventuallyImmutable, ParentOf<Element>, Processor, Replaceable, Validatable, Versioned, XMLSerialisable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractWorkflow, WorkflowImpl

    public interface Workflow
extends Processor, ChildOf<WorkflowContainer>, ParentOf<Element>
    A workflow is a linear list of Element objects which sits in a WorkflowContainer.

    When a workflow processes an input, it has its Element objects process the data sequentially, for example: input -> lement1 -> data1 -> Element2 -> data2 -> ... -> LastElement -> output.

    The Workflow's input and output types are independent of its Elements, and are set at the workflow's construction.

    It is perfectly legal to have the wrong input/output types for the workflow, or to have neighbouring elements be type-incompatible. In these situations, the workflow will return false for isValid(), and should have a way to inform the user (eg. in the associated view there might be connectors between neighbouring elements which are red if incompatible).

    NB. For two elements to be type-compatible, the previous Element's output type must be castable to the next Element's input type.

    However, a Workflow MUST be type-compatible with its parent WorkflowContainer. This is done so that all code related to checking neighbouring elements' data types is in Workflow (and nowhere else). Otherwise all WorkflowContainers would have to worry about whether its Workflows match it's data types. If this assertion is ever broken, a ClassCastException is thrown.

    • Method Detail

      • getInvalidlyOrderedElements

        List<Element> getInvalidlyOrderedElements()
        Returns the subset of this workflow's children which are invalid because their output type doesn't match the next element's input type. If this workflow's input type doesn't match the first element's input type, the list will also contain a null.
        Returns:
        the child elements that are invalid due to their order in this workflow.

      • withChildren

        Workflow withChildren(List<Element> newChildren)
        Description copied from interface: ParentOf
        Return a version of this with the given children.

        If this object can be mutated it will be, with this being returned. Otherwise a clone of this will be created with the given children.

        Specified by:
        withChildren in interface ParentOf<Element>
        Parameters:
        newChildren - the children to be given to the returned object.
        Returns:
        a version of this with the given children.

        Description copied from interface: EventuallyImmutable
